text: A Lemma on Inequalities Maxim Bogdan Abstract The purpose of this article is to ﬁnd an upper bound (but not symmetric, as we will see) for the power mean of order k of n numbers using just elementary methods, and to see how to use it in some applications. Let us start our journey with a known result Theorem 1. If a and b are real numbers such that a ≥ b ≥ 0 and k is a positive integer, then for all ck ∈ (0, 1 k√2 − 1 ] the following inequality is true: k√ ak + bk ≤ a + b ck . Proof. We have k√ak + bk ≤ a + b ck ⇐⇒ a k + bk ≤ a k + k∑ i=1 (k i ) · a k−i · bi ci k From a ≥ b it follows that a k+ k∑ i=1 (k i )·a k−i· bi ci k ≥ a k+ k∑ i=1 (k i )· bk ci k = a k+bk· [ k∑ i=1 (k i ) · ( 1 ck )i] = a k+bk· [(1 + 1 ck )k − 1 ] ≥ ≥ a k + bk ⇐⇒ (1 + 1 ck )k − 1 ≥ 1 ⇐⇒ 1 + 1 ck ≥ k√2 ⇐⇒ ck ≤ 1 k√2 − 1 It is not diﬃcult to see that ck = 1 k√2−1 is the best constant, because, for a = b ̸= 0, a k√2 ≤ a + a ck =⇒ k√2 ≤ 1 + 1 ck =⇒ ck ≤ 1 k√2 − 1 . Equality occurs when a = b or b = 0. Now, let us prove a more general result: Theorem 2. If a0 ≥ a1 ≥ a2 ≥ · · · ≥ an are positive real numbers, then the following inequality is satisﬁed for all ck ∈ (0, 1 k√2 − 1 ] : k √ ak 0 + ak 1 + · · · + ak n ≤ a0 + a1 ck + a2 c2 k + · · · + an cn k . Applying Theorem 1, k √ak 0 + ak 1 + · · · + ak n = k √a0 + (ak 1 + · · · + ak n) ≤ a0 + k √ak 1 + · · · + ak n ck k √ ak 1 + ak 2 + · · · + ak n = k √ak 1 + (ak 2 + · · · + ak n) ≤ a1 + k √ ak 2 + · · · + ak n ck ... k √ ak n−2 + ak n−1 + ak n = k √ ak n−2 + (ak n−1 + ak n) ≤ an−2 + k √ak n−1 + ak n ck k √ak n−1 + ak n ≤ an−1 + an ck Combining these n inequalities we get the desired result. Equality occurs if and only if ai = k √ak i+1 + ak i+2 + · · · + ak n, i = 0, 1, . . . , n − 1, i.e. ai = k√2n−i−1 · m, i = 0, 1, . . . , n − 1. So, the main result that we proved in this article is: k √ak 0 + ak 1 + · · · + ak n ≤ a0 + a1( k√2 − 1) + a2( k√2 − 1) 2 + · · · + an( k√2 − 1) n, for all a0 ≥ a1 ≥ · · · ≥ an > 0. Applications 1 Let a and b two non-negative real numbers with a ≥ b. Prove that the following inequality holds: √ a2 + b2 + 3√a3 + b3 + 4√ a4 + b4 ≤ 3a + b. Solution.
